content:
A colleague of mine (who I'm not sure is on this server, so I'm asking on their behalf) came up with/discovered an interesting construction.

Let F:C×Cop→SetsF : \mathcal{C}\times\mathcal{C}^{\rm op}\to\mathbf{Sets}F:C×Cop→Sets be a functor. The "dinatural category of elements" of FFF is the category whose objects are pairs (c,x)(c, x)(c,x) with x∈F(c,c)x\in F(c,c)x∈F(c,c). A morphism (c,x)→(d,y)(c,x)\to (d,y)(c,x)→(d,y) is f:c→df : c\to df:c→d such that F(f,1)(x)=F(1,f)(y)F(f,1)(x) = F(1,f)(y)F(f,1)(x)=F(1,f)(y). Composition and identities are clear. This is equipped with a projection functor π:el(F)→C\pi : \mathrm{el}(F)\to Cπ:el(F)→C, but it is apparently not a discrete fibration like the usual category of elements. The connected components of el(F)\mathrm{el}(F)el(F) correspond to elements of the coend of FFF, similarly to how the colimit of a presheaf is the set of connected components of its category of elements. The set of sections of π\piπ in Cat\mathbf{Cat}Cat correpond to elements of the end of FFF, similar to how sections of the discrete fibration of the category of elements of a presheaf correspond to elements of the limit of FFF.

Can others elaborate on this? Does it have a name?

I also observed that for any functor G:A×Aop→BG : \mathcal{A}\times\mathcal{A}^{\rm op}\to \mathcal{B}G:A×Aop→B and b∈Bb \in Bb∈B one can form a "dinatural comma category" whose objects are pairs (a,f:G(a,a)→b)(a, f : G(a,a)\to b)(a,f:G(a,a)→b), a morphism (a,f)→(a′,f′)(a, f)\to (a',f')(a,f)→(a′,f′) is a morphism g:a→a′g : a \to a'g:a→a′ such that f∘G(g,1)=f′∘G(1,g)f\circ G(g, 1)=f'\circ G(1,g)f∘G(g,1)=f′∘G(1,g). This "dinatural category of elements" is a particular example of this construction applied to the (ordinary, usual) Yoneda embedding y:Cop×C→[C×Cop;Sets]y : \mathcal{C}^{\rm op}\times\mathcal{C}\to [\mathcal{C}\times\mathcal{C}^{\rm op};\mathbf{Sets}]y:Cop×C→[C×Cop;Sets]. So, this leads me to ask whether there is some specialization of the theory of 2-categories which allows for such "dinatural comma categories" to be expressed as a 2-limit in some way.

Taking the discussion in a somewhat orthogonal direction, just as the "category of elements" construction for a presheaf can be generalized to the Grothendieck construction for indexed categories, it is clear how to generalize this construction to give a "dinatural Grothendieck" construction for functors F:C×Cop→CatF : \mathcal{C}\times\mathcal{C}^{\rm op}\to\mathbf{Cat}F:C×Cop→Cat, so if anyone wants to comment on that, feel free

I also very recently stumbled upon the very same definition! The main problem that left me a bit dissatisfied with this definition is that you do not ever talk about morphisms between xxx and yyy in any fiber, and this is obviously connected to the problem that given a morphism f:c→df : c \to df:c→d one cannot directly relate P(c,c)P(c,c)P(c,c) and P(d,d)P(d,d)P(d,d)... so possibly a more enlightened 2-categorical definition might include some sort of laxity instead of the "wedge-like" equation.

Just another way you can see this category.
In general, given a functor π:C→D\pi: \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D}π:C→D, one can consider a category of sections of π\piπ, whose

  • objects are sections of π\piπ, that is, functors s:D→Cs: \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C}s:D→C such that π∘s=idD\pi \circ s = \mathrm{id}_\mathcal{D}π∘s=idD​,
  • morphisms from sss to ttt are natural transformations α:s⇒t\alpha: s \Rightarrow tα:s⇒t such that, for all objects ddd of D\mathcal{D}D, π(αd)=idd\pi(\alpha_d) = \mathrm{id}_dπ(αd​)=idd​.

Let N\mathbb{N}N denote the monoid of natural numbers with addition, seen as a category with a single object.
An endo-profunctor FFF on C\mathcal{C}C determines and can be reconstructed from a functor πF:CF→N\pi_F: \mathcal{C}_F \to \mathbb{N}πF​:CF​→N, where

  • CF\mathcal{C}_FCF​ is obtained by adjoining a morphism x:c→dx: c \to dx:c→d to C\mathcal{C}C for every element x∈F(c,d)x \in F(c, d)x∈F(c,d), and quotienting by the equations gxf=ygxf = ygxf=y whenever F(g,f)(x)=yF(g, f)(x) = yF(g,f)(x)=y,
  • πF\pi_FπF​ is defined by πF(f)=0\pi_F(f) = 0πF​(f)=0 if fff is a morphism in C\mathcal{C}C and πF(x)=1\pi_F(x) = 1πF​(x)=1 if xxx is an element of the profunctor.

Then an equivalent description of your "dinatural category of elements" is the category of sections of πF\pi_FπF​.

Notice that “endo-profunctors” are essentially equivalent to “categories over N\mathbb{N}N”; every endo-profunctor determines a category over N\mathbb{N}N the way that I described, and, vice versa, every functor π:D→N\pi: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{N}π:D→N determines a profunctor FπF_\piFπ​ on the subcategory π−1(0)\pi^{-1}(0)π−1(0) of D\mathcal{D}D, by letting Fπ(c,d)≔{x∈D(c,d)∣π(x)=1}F_\pi(c, d) \coloneqq \{ x \in \mathcal{D}(c, d) \mid \pi(x) = 1 \}Fπ​(c,d):={x∈D(c,d)∣π(x)=1}, with the action determined by morphism composition in D\mathcal{D}D.
The two constructions are inverse to each other up to natural isomorphism.

This is sometimes a nice perspective because it shows you that a “category together with an endo-profunctor on it” can be faithfully encoded as the data of a “category [but a different one!] together with an N\mathbb{N}N-valued, additive measure on its morphisms”.
Then your category of sections has, as objects, objects of this category together with a measure-1 endomorphism on them; this may sometimes be interpreted as a category of dynamical systems...

I see this story from a slightly different point:

  • A monad in profunctors is a category
  • A mere endo-1-cell in profunctors is a (directed) graph

In such directed graph, you can study iterated compositions of the profunctors with itself, studying "flows" of the discrete dynamical system prescribed by the endo-profunctors.

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

Notice that “endo-profunctors” are essentially equivalent to “categories over N\mathbb{N}N”; every endo-profunctor determines a category over N\mathbb{N}N the way that I described, and, vice versa, every functor π:D→N\pi: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{N}π:D→N determines a profunctor FπF_\piFπ​ on the subcategory π−1(0)\pi^{-1}(0)π−1(0) of D\mathcal{D}D, by letting Fπ(c,d)≔{x∈D(c,d)∣π(x)=1}F_\pi(c, d) \coloneqq \{ x \in \mathcal{D}(c, d) \mid \pi(x) = 1 \}Fπ​(c,d):={x∈D(c,d)∣π(x)=1}, with the action determined by morphism composition in D\mathcal{D}D.
The two constructions are inverse to each other up to natural isomorphism.

Sorry, this is not true, lol --- it is true that π↦Fπ\pi \mapsto F_\piπ↦Fπ​ is a left inverse of F↦πFF \mapsto \pi_FF↦πF​, but not the other way around
Indeed, I was starting to express doubt about it. Not categories over NN...

Yes I was thinking about the (true) fact that profunctors = categories over the arrow and I turned it too hastily into endo-profunctors = categories over the loop, but it's only an “inclusion” in the latter case.
I'd hasard the conjecture that endo-profunctors = categories with a strict Conduché functor to N\mathbb{N}N...

Thus Conduché functors into B correspond to pseudofunctors from B, regarded as a locally discrete bicategory, to the bicategory Prof.

Well this seems to confirm it, since pseudofunctors from N\mathbb{N}N to Prof\mathrm{Prof}Prof classify endo-profunctors.

So my intuition is that a Conduché functor μ:C→N\mu: \mathcal{C} \to \mathbb{N}μ:C→N is like a measure on morphisms of C\mathcal{C}C that is additive wrt composition, and with the property that every morphism of length nnn can be decomposed into nnn morphisms of length 111; this is the sort of thing that seems quite natural in modelling some categories of discrete-time processes

I think the "standard" construction that this is most closely related to is the "two-sided category of elements", which associates to any profunctor C↛DC\nrightarrow DC↛D a [[two-sided discrete fibration]] C←E→DC \leftarrow E \to DC←E→D, which is a fibration over DDD and an opfibration over CCC, compatibly, and discrete over C×DC\times DC×D (but not over CCC or DDD individually). Then if it should happen that C=DC=DC=D, you can pull back along the diagonal C→C×CC\to C\times CC→C×C and I think you get your construction.

Paige North made me aware of this conversation.
Some related concepts are discussed in sections 2.2.7 & 2.2.8 of my PhD thesis:
https://lirias.kuleuven.be/retrieve/581985

  • I have an even more general version of the category of elements with first component in C\mathbb{C}C and second component in the image of a functor F:Tw(C)→SetsF : Tw(\mathbb{C}) \to \mathbf{Sets}F:Tw(C)→Sets, with Tw(C)Tw(\mathbb{C})Tw(C) the twisted arrow category over C\mathbb{C}C. This is more general than the above because we have a functor Tw(C)→Cop×CTw(\mathbb{C}) \to \mathbb{C}^{op} \times \mathbb{C}Tw(C)→Cop×C.
  • Relatedly, I define dependent ends and coends via functors on twisted arrow categories.

I hadn't seen these concepts elsewhere before but was hesitant to claim them as novel.

(Small note: My PhD thesis and some earlier writings of mine suffer from an unfortunate idiom mixup, where I have been misinterpreting "slice category" as "category of slices" and have thus used the word "slice" to refer to a single object of the slice category, rather than the entire category.)
An annoying detail about Zulip is you need double dollar signs to render in-line math.

The lax end and lax coend also seem related, but different:
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.01522

@anuyts Paige North made me aware of your reply. I think that similarly to how the dinatural category of elements of a profunctor PPP is a pullback of the canonical discrete two-sided fibration PPP induces, your definition of the category of elements for a functor F:Tw(C)→SetsF:Tw(\mathcal{C}) \to \bf{Sets}F:Tw(C)→Sets is a pullback of the canonical discrete dependent two-sided fibration PPP induces.

First, we notice that

Tw(C)≅∫(op∘C/−)Tw(\mathcal{C}) \cong \int \left( \text{op} \circ \mathcal{C}/- \right)Tw(C)≅∫(op∘C/−)

Where the rhs is the Grothendieck construction of the functor op∘C/−:C→Cat\text{op} \circ \mathcal{C}/-:\mathcal{C}\to \bf{Cat}op∘C/−:C→Cat.

Now, abstracting away and considering a category AAA, and functors B:A→CatB:A\to \bf{Cat}B:A→Cat and C:∫(op∘B)→CatC:\int (\text{op}\circ B) \to \bf{Cat}C:∫(op∘B)→Cat, we can make a new category ∬C\iint C∬C that has

  • Objects: An object is a triple (a,b,c):∑a:A∑b:B(a)C(a,b)(a,b,c):\sum_{a:A}\sum_{b:B(a)}C(a,b)(a,b,c):∑a:A​∑b:B(a)​C(a,b).
  • Morphisms: For (a,b,c),(a′,b′,c′):∬C(a,b,c), (a',b',c'):\iint C(a,b,c),(a′,b′,c′):∬C, their hom-set is

∑α:homA(a,a′)∑β:homB(a′)(B(α)b,b′)homC(a′,B(α)b)(C(α,idB(α)b)c,C(idB(α)b,β)c′) \sum_{\alpha:\text{hom}_{A}(a,a')} \sum_{\beta: \text{hom}_{B(a')}(B(\alpha)b,b')} \text{hom}_{C(a',B(\alpha)b)}(C(\alpha,\text{id}_{B(\alpha)b})c, C(\text{id}_{B(\alpha)b}, \beta)c')α:homA​(a,a′)∑​β:homB(a′)​(B(α)b,b′)∑​homC(a′,B(α)b)​(C(α,idB(α)b​)c,C(idB(α)b​,β)c′)

image.png

This category is an opfibration over AAA and a "local fibration" over ∫B\int B∫B (without the op\text{op}op) with some compatibility conditions that generalize the (non-dependent) two-sided fibrations.

Applying this construction to

F:∫(op∘C/−)≅Tw(C)→Sets→CatF:\int \left( \text{op} \circ \mathcal{C}/- \right) \cong Tw(\mathcal{C}) \to \bf{Sets} \to \bf{Cat}F:∫(op∘C/−)≅Tw(C)→Sets→Cat

Gives a category ∬F\iint F∬F, together with a local fibration over ∫(C/−)≅C→\int (\mathcal{C}/-)\cong \mathcal{C}^\to∫(C/−)≅C→. Pulling it back along the inclusion id(−):C→C→\text{id}(-): \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}^\toid(−):C→C→ gives your category of elements as defined in 2.2.37 of your thesis.

I commented something and deleted it here because I thought it was silly/obvious but others may find it interesting so I will re-post it.

Mike Shulman said:

I think the "standard" construction that this is most closely related to is the "two-sided category of elements", which associates to any profunctor C↛DC\nrightarrow DC↛D a [[two-sided discrete fibration]] C←E→DC \leftarrow E \to DC←E→D, which is a fibration over DDD and an opfibration over CCC, compatibly, and discrete over C×DC\times DC×D (but not over CCC or DDD individually). .

If P:C×Dop→SetsP : C\times D^{\rm op}\to\mathbf{Sets}P:C×Dop→Sets is a profunctor, then the set of sections of the two-sided discrete fibration ∫P→C×D\int P \to C\times D∫P→C×D should be the ordinary limit of PPP. This is evidently related to the theorem that, for P:Dop→SetsP: D^{\rm op}\to\mathbf{Sets}P:Dop→Sets a presheaf, the set of sections of the functor ∫P→D\int P\to D∫P→D is the limit of PPP, but it is different enough that it not literally an immediate specialization.

Patrick Nicodemus said:

The connected components of el(F)\mathrm{el}(F)el(F) correspond to elements of the coend of FFF, similarly to how the colimit of a presheaf is the set of connected components of its category of elements.

I think this is not true. A morphism f:c→df : c \to df:c→d in C\mathcal CC is sent by the endoprofunctor FFF to a commuting square in Set. The coend will only identify elements of F(c,c)F(c, c)F(c,c) and F(d,d)F(d, d)F(d,d) if they come from the same element of F(c,d)F(c, d)F(c,d), which is a stronger condition than asking that they map to the same element in F(d,c)F(d, c)F(d,c), which is the condition to be in the same connected component of this dinatural category of elements.
